Example 11.2. Basic quotient rule.

Suppose \(w(x)=(x-3)(x+2)\text{.}\) Find \(w'(x)\text{.}\)

\begin{equation*} \begin{aligned}[t] w'(x) \amp= \frac{d}{dx}\left((x-3)(x+2)\right)\\ \amp= (x-3)\frac{d}{dx}(x+2) + (x+2)\frac{d}{dx}(x-3)\\ \amp= (x-3)(1) + (x+2)(1)\\ w'(x) \amp= 2x-1 \end{aligned} \end{equation*}

Notice that we could have expanded \(w(x)\) first by multiplying the right-hand side, then taken the derivative of the result term-by-term.
